Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating jamming in iceberg-choked fjords with field observations, laboratory experiments, and numerical models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical:
This award is jointly funded by the Condensed Matter Physics Program and the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in Math and Physical Sciences and the Artic Natural Sciences Program in Geosciences. The polar regions of our planet are home to many dynamic physical processes. Although the word "glacier" may invoke connotations of stoic and slow-moving mountains of ice whose changes are indistinguishable to the eye, this is not always the case. Among the most active regions of glaciological activity are the massive coastal fjords in Greenland. Rivers of ice which are 5-10 km wide and up to 1 km deep are rapidly flowing towards the ocean. At the end of these glaciers, where the ice meets the sea, icebergs are constantly breaking off or "calving" into the ocean. Approximately 30-50% of all ice discharged into the ocean occurs through calving, as opposed to other mechanisms such as melting. Unfortunately, the physical processes which control calving are not well understood. One possible influence is the presence of an ice mélange, which is a floating layer of icebergs and sea ice extending many kilometers away from the front of the glacier. The mélange is essentially a large-scale, quasi-two dimensional granular material, which can potentially have a large impact on calving rates and our ability to detect iceberg calving. This collaborative project aims to determine the correct physical description of ice mélange mechanics, as well as its influences on iceberg calving. This is accomplished through an interdisciplinary combination of satellite imagery, small-scale laboratory experiments, and theoretical modeling. By bringing together ideas in condensed matter physics to study large-scale glaciological processes, the project sheds new light on the underlying mechanisms which shape the polar regions of our planet.

Technical:
The primary goal of this project is to characterize the rheology of ice mélange, a closely-packed granular material composed of icebergs and sea ice that is found in fjords throughout Greenland. Ice mélange is unique among granular materials in that it contains exceptionally large clasts (10s to 100s of meters in scale in all directions), is constrained to flow in a quasi-two-dimensional setting, and floats in its own melt. Seasonal variations in ice mélange motion and extent are well-correlated with seasonal variations in iceberg calving rates, suggesting that ice mélange is an important control on outlet glacier and ice sheet stability. The dynamics, energetics, and oceanographic consequences of ice mélange are essentially unexplored. The research team's aim is to study ice mélange by combining analysis of field observations with laboratory experiments and numerical modeling. Satellite imagery, along with previously collected time lapse photography and terrestrial radar data, is analyzed to produce ice mélange velocity fields and quantify iceberg-size distributions. This work provides new insights into ice mélange kinematics and composition, and serves as a benchmark for laboratory and numerical modeling experiments. In addition, experiments are conducted in which synthetic icebergs in a water tank are pushed by a model terminus. These experiments study jamming of particles that model icebergs during and between calving events to investigate stress transmission through ice mélange. Finally, numerical experiments are performed in which ice mélange is simulated using discrete particle and continuum models adapted from previous work on granular materials. The model rheology can be adjusted to find a description of ice mélange that is consistent with field observations and laboratory experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Glaciers that terminate in the ocean are referred to as tidewater or marine-terminating glaciers. Changes in tidewater glacier length and volume are strongly influenced by rates of iceberg calving and submarine melting at the ice-ocean boundary. Because these processes cause tidewater glaciers to retreat more rapidly than land-terminating glaciers, tidewater glaciers disproportionately contribute to sea level rise.

Some tidewater glaciers calve icebergs faster than they melt or can be evacuated from fjords, producing dense packs of icebergs or “ice mélange”. Observations and simple theoretical considerations suggest that ice mélange may influence iceberg calving by transmitting resistive stresses from fjord walls back onto the glacier margins. Thus, ice mélange may affect rates of ice discharge and associated sea level rise from some of Greenland’s largest fjords. This study focused on developing a physical understanding of ice mélange that would be suitable for glacier flow models. Additionally, ice mélange represents a unique example of a granular material, such as sand, but on a geophysical scale where the individual “grains” (icebergs) are 25 meters in diameter or larger. Thus, one of the goals of this collaborative grant between glaciologists and physicists was to test whether the physical understanding of small-scale granular materials that has been developed over the last 25 years can be successfully applied on the geophysical scale.

During the project we used a variety of methods to study ice mélange, including laboratory experiments, computer simulations, and analysis of field and satellite data. The key results from the study are that (i) ice mélange can inhibit calving of icebergs if the ice mélange is more than three times as long as it is wide, (ii) its flow can be reasonably approximated by models developed for other, significantly smaller, granular materials, and (ii) failure of ice mélange is preceded by a loss of flow coherence. These results provide physical mechanisms for including ice mélange in glacier and ice sheet simulations aimed at predicting freshwater discharge into the oceans and solidified the importance of ice mélange in the dynamics of tidewater glaciers. As the global temperature continues to increase and mass loss from the polar regions becomes more dynamic, our understanding of ice mélange and other complex systems at the ice-ocean boundary will become more important in predicting the ultimate fate of our planet’s large ice sheets. [1] 

This award contained several broader impacts in both the scientific community and the general public. The dynamics of ice mélange occur on ~1-hour long timescales, are visually striking, and can capture the imagination with the immense scale of the problem. The work served as an example of interdisciplinary physics at its finest where boundaries were pushed in both fields due to their mutual interaction. The work also spawned several public outreach opportunities. PI Burton discussed the work in professional development seminars for sustainability-interested faculty in Atlanta (The Piedmont Project) and integrated the work into events for the Atlanta Science Festival. PI Dennin has integrated results from the work into his science Podcasts, panels at ComicCons and television appearances.
